There is created and established a recreation executive board for the city. 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 168/425 (Ord. of 9-26-1989, § 15-1(a)) Sec. 50-32. - Composition, compensation. The recreation executive board shall consist of not less than five nor more than 12 persons, serving without pay. (Ord. of 9-26-1989, § 15-1(b)) Sec. 50-33. - Appointment. The members of the recreation executive board shall be appointed by the mayor and council. (Ord. of 9-26-1989, § 15-1(b)) Sec. 50-34. - Terms. The term of office of the members of the recreation executive board shall be three years or until their successors are appointed and qualified, except that the members of such a board first appointed shall be appointed for such terms that the term of some members shall expire annually thereafter. Appointments shall become effective on July 1 of each calendar year. (Ord. of 9-26-1989, § 15-1(b)) Sec. 50-35. - Filling vacancies. Vacancies in the membership of the recreation executive board occurring otherwise than by expiration of term shall be filled by another appointment for the unexpired term. (Ord. of 9-26-1989, § 15-1(b)) Sec. 50-36. - Ex officio members. In addition, all members of the recreation committee of the city council shall be ex officio members of the recreation executive board. (Ord. of 9-26-1989, § 15-1(b)) Sec. 50-37. - Removal from office. Members of the recreation executive board may be removed from office by the mayor and council at any city council meeting if it is ascertained that the members are not serving in the best interest of the recreation program. (Ord. of 9-26-1989, § 15-1(c)) Sec. 50-38. - Officers. At such times as shall be appropriate, the mayor and council shall, from among the membership of the recreation executive board, appoint a chairman and other officers of the recreation executive board upon the advice and recommendation of the board. The duties of these officers shall be as follows: (1) Chairman. The chairman shall preside at all regular meetings and is expected to work in close harmony with the recreation director. The chairman shall have the authority to appoint and dissolve any committees he deems necessary. The recreation director may appoint the chairman to assume the duties normally done by the director if he is not available to perform such duties. In addition, the mayor may appoint the chairman or any other 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 169/425 member of the executive board to assume the duties of the director on a temporary basis, with or without pay, in the event it becomes necessary. (2) Vice-chairman. Upon the absence or inability of the chairman to perform his duties, the vice-chairman shall have the same duties and authority as the chairman. (3) Secretary. The secretary shall be under the supervision and direction of the chairman. He shall record minutes of all meetings held by or pertaining to the recreation executive board and shall see that each member is notified of forthcoming meetings in advance of such meetings. A copy of the minutes shall be submitted to the mayor and council after approval of such minutes. (4) Treasurer. The treasurer shall be under the supervision and direction of the chairman. He shall receive all monies and deposit same in a bank designated by the mayor and council. The secretary and treasurer positions may be combined as to allow these duties to be occupied by one individual. (Ord. of 9-26-1989, § 15-2; Ord. of 4-6-2000, § 1) Sec. 50-39. - Duties. The duties of the recreation executive board shall include the following: (1) The outlining, planning and recommendation of a complete recreational program. (2) Planning and recommendation for the financing thereof. (3) Planning and recommendation for the securing of voluntary and other workers thereof. (4) Planning and recommendation for the administration of recreational programs. (5) Planning and recommendation for the acquisition and providing of additional recreational facilities. (6) Assist in preparing and submitting to the mayor and council a proposed budget with respect to the recreational program or programs, and making recommendations relating thereto. (Ord. of 9-26-1989, § 15-3) Sec. 50-40. - Meetings. 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 170/425 (a) The regular meeting of the recreation executive board shall be held on the first Monday of each month. (b) A quorum shall consist of 50 percent of the members of the board. (c) The chairman of the recreation executive board shall not vote, unless there is a tie vote among a quorum of board members on any given issue. (Ord. of 9-26-1989, § 15-4)

div.head: Chapter 54 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- Cross reference— Buildings and building construction, ch. 14; environment, ch. 34; flood control, ch. 38; manufactured homes, ch. 42; streets and sidewalks, ch. 66; utilities, ch. 78; zoning, app. A; subdivisions, app. B. State Law reference— Coordinated and comprehensive planning by counties and municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Secs. 54-1—54-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION FOOTNOTE(S): --- (2) --- Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. Sec. 54-31. - Created. The city planning commission is created and established. (Code 1983, § 2-8) Sec. 54-32. - Composition. The city planning commission shall consist of seven members appointed by council. Three of the members shall constitute a quorum and shall be authorized to transact the business of the planning commission. Voting on the issues before the commission shall be by role call vote and such vote along with the stated business or motion shall be recorded in the official minutes of the planning and zoning meeting. Once a quorum of members are present, a majority of the members present shall be required to pass any measure before the city planning commission. (Code 1983, § 2-8; Ord. of 10-18-2007(2)) 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 171/425 Sec. 54-33. - Terms. The terms of the members of the city planning commission shall be for two years. The city planning commission seats shall be designated as seats 1—7. City planning commission seats 1—4 shall initially be appointed to a three-year term beginning in January of 2008 and at the expiration of the initial three-year term shall be appointed for two-year terms thereafter. City planning commission seats 5—7 shall be appointed to a two-year term beginning in January of 2008 and shall be appointed for two-year terms thereafter. (Code 1983, § 2-8; Ord. of 11-1-2007(1)) Sec. 54-34. - Removal of member. The council shall have the authority to remove any member of the city planning commission at any time. The removed member shall have the right to appeal the removal to council. (Code 1983, § 2-8; Ord. of 10-18-2007(3)) Sec. 54-35. - Filling vacancies. Any vacancy in the membership of the city planning commission shall be filled for the unexpired term by the council. (Code 1983, § 2-8; Ord. of 10-18-2007(4)) Sec. 54-36. - Compensation. All members of the city planning commission shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties if approved by council. (Code 1983, § 2-8; Ord. of 10-18-2007(5)) Sec. 54-37. - Reserved. Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Oct. 18, 2007, repealed § 54-37 which pertained to appointment of alternate or provision members and derived from § 2-11 of an ordinance adopted March 16, 2001. Sec. 54-38. - Officers. (a) The city planning commission shall consist of a chairman, vice-chairman, and secretary. The city council shall appoint the chairman, vice-chairman, and secretary from the members of the city planning commission. The term of the chairman, vice-chairman, and secretary shall be one year beginning January 1, of each year and ending December 31, of each year. (b) The chairman shall be in charge of conducting all meetings and the vice-chairman shall assume the responsibilities of the chairman when the chairman is absent. The secretary shall be responsible for taking down the minutes of all meetings. The chairman, vice-chairman, and secretary shall be responsible for the preparation of the official minutes of the city planning commission meetings. The chairman, vice-chairman, and secretary shall vote on all issues before the city planning commission. (Code 1983, § 2-9; Ord. of 10-18-2007(7)) 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 172/425 Sec. 54-39. - Procedure. (a) The city council shall promulgate the rules of procedure for the city planning commission and determine the date and time of the city planning commission meeting. All meetings of the planning commission shall be open to the public and all records of the planning commission shall be a public record. (b) The city planning commission procedure shall be the same procedure used by city council and the procedure required by the laws of the state, the City Charter, and this Code. (Code 1983, § 2-9; Ord. of 10-18-2007(8)) Sec. 54-40. - Staff. The city council may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for the effective operation of the city planning commission and the city council may contract with the state planning agency and with city planners and other consultants for such services as maybe required. (Code 1983, § 2-9; Ord. of 10-18-2007(9)) Sec. 54-41. - Limitation on expenditures. The expenditures of the city planning commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for the purpose by the mayor and city council. (Code 1983, § 2-9) Sec. 54-42. - Powers and duties. The city planning commission shall have the powers, duties and responsibilities as set forth in the Official Code of Georgia, the City Charter, and this Code. The city planning commission shall constitute the recommending authority to city council for issues related to zoning and planning. (Code 1983, § 2-10; Ord. of 10-18-2007(10)) Secs. 54-43—54-99. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - DEVELOPMENT IMPACT FEES Sec. 54-100. - Short title, authority and applicability. (a) This article shall be known and may be cited as the "City of Bloomingdale Development Impact Fee Ordinance". (b) The city has the authority to adopt this article pursuant to the "Home Rule" provisions of the Constitution of the State of Georgia, delineated in O.C.G.A. tit. 36, ch. 71. (c) This article shall apply to all land and property developed within the service delivery areas of the city effective with the dates specified at the ratification of the ordinance from which this article derives by the mayor and city 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 173/425 council. (Ord. of 6-19-2008, § 54-100) Sec. 54-101. - Intent and purpose. (a) This article is intended to implement and be consistent with the city's comprehensive land use plan adopted in accordance with O.C.G.A. tit. 36, ch. 70, and pursuant to the standards and procedures established by state agencies where applicable. (b) The purpose of this article is to regulate the use and development of land so as to assure that new development bears a proportionate share of the cost of system improvements necessary to provide facilities and infrastructure needed to serve an increased population from new developments within the city and the surrounding areas. It is specifically acknowledged that this article has approached the problem of determining such proportionate share in a conservative and reasonable manner, in accordance with O.C.G.A. tit. 36, ch. 71. (Ord. of 6-19-2008, § 54-105) Sec. 54-102. - Rules of construction. (a) The provisions of this article shall be liberally construed so as to effectively carry out its purpose in the interest of providing necessary facilities and infrastructure to insure the public's health, safety and welfare. (b) For the purposes of administration and enforcement of this article, unless otherwise stated in this article, the following rules of construction shall apply to the text of this article: (1) In case of any difference of meaning or implication between the text of this article and any caption, illustration, summary table, or illustrative table, the text shall control. (2) The word "shall" is mandatory and not discretionary; the word "may" is permissive. (3) Words used in the present tense shall include the future; and words used in the singular shall include the plural, and the plural shall include the singular, unless the context clearly indicates the contrary. (4) The phrase "used for" includes "arranged for," "designed for," "maintained for," or "occupied for." (5) The word "person" includes an individual, a corporation, a partnership, an incorporated association, or any other similar entity. 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 174/425 (6) Unless the context clearly indicates the contrary, where a regulation involves two or more items, conditions, provisions or events connected by the conjunction "and", "or", or "either . . . or", the conjunction shall interpreted as follows: a. "And" indicates that all connected terms, conditions, provisions or events shall apply. b. "Or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions or events may apply singly but not in combination. c. "Either . . . or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions or events shall apply singly but not in combination. (7) The word "includes" shall not limit a term to the specific example but is intended to extend its meaning to all other instances or circumstances of like kind or character. (8) Any road, street, water or wastewater facility, easement or right-of-way used to define development impact fee district boundaries may be considered to be within any district it bounds for the purposes of the assessment and utilization of these fees. (Ord. of 6-19-2008, § 54-110) Sec. 54-103. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Building permit means the document issued by the city authorizing the construction, repair, alteration or addition to a structure, or authorizing the installation of a mobile home or recreational vehicle. For the purposes of this article, a building permit also means a change of use permit. Capital improvement means any property, facility, or structure constructed, installed or purchased or any improvement, expansion or enhancement made to an existing property, facility or structure with a useful life of ten years or more. Capital improvement element means that portion of the city's comprehensive land use plan which sets out projected needs for system improvements during a planning horizon established that will meet the anticipated need for system improvements, and a description of anticipated funding sources for each required improvement. City means Bloomingdale, Georgia, but may also be interchangeable with the city council as the context requires. Comprehensive plan means the Comprehensive Land Use Plan for the City of Bloomingdale, Georgia. 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 175/425 Developer means any individual, corporation, partnership, association or any other similar entity who engages in development activity. Development activity means any construction or expansion of a building, structure, any change in the use of a building or structure, or any change in the use of land requiring the issuance of a building permit. Director means the mayor, city administrator, and/or the official(s) designated to administer the various provisions of this article. Encumber means to legally obligate by contract, resolution or otherwise commit to use by appropriation by an official act of the city. Development impact fee district means a geographic area identified by the city in which a defined city-provided service is provided. Facilities and/or infrastructure means any land, buildings, fixtures, furnishings and any other related items used in providing services by the city to the general citizenry. Feepayor means that person who pays a development impact fee or his/her successor in interest with the right of entitlement to any refund of a previously paid development impact fee which is required by this article and which has been expressly transferred or assigned to the successor in interest. In the absence of an expressed transfer or assignment of the right of entitlement to any refund of previously paid development impact fee right of entitlement shall be not be deemed to "run with the land." Individual fee calculation study means an engineering and/or economic documentation prepared by a feepayor to allow determination of the development impact fee other than by use of the fee schedule established by the city. Individual fee determination means the development impact fee determined by the director on the basis of an individual fee calculation study. Level of service means a measure or estimate of facilities and / or infrastructure provided to the general citizenry based on customary business practices by the city, consistent with the demands related to all land uses and consistent with state and federal regulations and prudent engineering and operating practices. Methodology report means a report prepared which provides an analysis and methodology for the determination of the development impact fee and the impact of development activity on the needs and cost of additional facilities and/or infrastructure. Present value means the discounted cash flow of past, present or future payments, contributions, or dedications of goods, services, materials, construction, or money; also may be stated as "current value." Project or development project means a particular development on an identified parcel of land. Project improvement means site improvements and facilities that are planned and designed to provide service for a particular development project and that are necessary for the use and convenience of the occupants or users of the project and are not system improvements. The character of the improvement shall control the determination of whether an improvement is a project improvement or a system improvement and the physical location of the improvement onsite or offsite shall not be considered determinative of whether an improvement is a project improvement or a system improvement. If an improvement or facility provides or will provide more than incidental service or facility capacity to persons other than users or occupants of a particular project, the improvement or facility is a system improvement and shall not be considered a project improvement. Proportionate share means that portion of the cost of system improvements which is reasonably related to the demands and needs of a project. Replacement value means the cost of replacing facilities and/or infrastructure at current market prices. 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 176/425 Service delivery area means the geographic areas defined and designated to receive government-provided public services from the relevant local governmental entities in accordance with the provisions of the Service Delivery Strategy Act of the State of Georgia as administered through the Georgia Department of Community Affairs. System improvement means facilities and/or infrastructure, provided by the city that are designed to provide service to the community at large, in contrast to a project improvement. System improvement cost means cost incurred to provide additional facilities and/or infrastructure needed to serve developments or new construction within the service area of the city, including, but not limited to, the construction contract price, surveying and engineering fees, related land acquisition cost, court cost, attorney and expert witness fees, and expenses incurred for qualified staff, engineer planner, architect or financial consultant for preparing or updating the capital improvement element, and administrative cost equal to three percent of the total amount of such costs. "System improvement cost" shall also include interest charges and other finance costs related to the issuance of bonds, notes or other financial obligations incurred by the city to finance capital improvements. (Ord. of 6-19-2008, § 54-118) Sec. 54-104. - Imposition of fee. (a) Any person who after July 1, 2008 engages in development activity shall pay a development impact fee in the manner set forth in this article. (b) No building permit for any development activity thereby required to pay a development impact fee pursuant to this article shall be issued by the city unless and until the required development impact fees have been paid. (Ord. of 6-19-2008, § 54-120) Sec. 54-105. - Computation of fee. (a) (1) At the option of the developer, the amount of the development impact fee may be determined from the fee schedule established by the city, and maintained in the office of the director and/or city clerk, or as per the provisions of subsection (2) below. (2) If a building permit is requested for a building with mixed uses, the fee shall be determined according to the fee schedule established by the city by apportioning the space committed to uses specified on the fee schedule. If the type of development activity for which a building permit is applied for is not specified on the fee schedule, the director shall use the fee applicable to the most nearly comparable type of land use on the fee schedule. The director shall be guided in the selection of a comparable type by the reports and studies done by the United States Environmental Protection Agency and/or the state, and/or the city department of public works, and/or professional organizations such as the American Society of Civil Engineers. If the director determines the fee by using from the above-named sources and applying the formula set forth in subsection (b) below. In the case of change of use, redevelopment or modification of an existing use which requires the issuance of a building permit, the development impact fee shall be based upon the net increase in the 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 177/425 fee for the new use as compared to the previous use. The director shall be guided in this determination by the above-named sources. (b) If a developer elects not to have the development impact fee determined according to subsection (a), above, then the developer may apply for an individual fee determination. A developer applying for an individual fee determination shall prepare and submit to the director an individual fee calculation study for the development activity for which a building permit is sought. The individual fee calculation study shall follow the prescribed methodologies and formats for the study established by the director, or, subject to the prior approval of the director, such other professionally accepted methodology that identifies a project's proportionate share. The developer shall attend a pre-application meeting with the director and no agreement or understanding in regard to data, assumptions or methodology shall be binding upon the city unless provided to the developer in writing. The service demand documentation submitted shall show the basis upon which the individual fee calculation was made, including but not limited to the following: (1) Documentation demonstrating the impact of the proposed development activity on the following city-provided services: a. Public safety. 1. Police. 2. Fire. 3. Emergency medical services. b. Parks and recreation. c. Community development. 1. Building inspection. 2. Code enforcement. d. Public works. 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 178/425 1. Streets. 2. Sidewalks. 3. Storm water/drainage. 4. Street lights. 5. Water. 6. Wastewater treatment. (2) Engineering or any other suitable report(s), study or documentation depicting service demands or city-provided services appropriate for the proposed development activity; (3) Cost documentation studies including documentation of the cost per unit of impact for construction and documentation credits attributable to the development activity which can be expected to be available to replace the portion of the service volume/demand generated by the development activity. This documentation shall be prepared and presented by qualified professionals in their respective fields and shall follow best professional practices and methodologies. The following formula, as explained in the methodology report, shall be used by the director to determine the development impact fee per unit of development based on the type of land use: [Unit Cost × Demand] - Credit = Proportionate Share Whereby: Unit cost = The average cost per unit of capacity to provide infrastructure or facilities within the service district. Demand = The average volume/capacity or demand expected to be utilized by a given land use on an annual basis. Credit = The average present value of future payments by a land use towards the retirement of debt incurred to construct facilities and infrastructure. The director shall provide the developer with a written individual fee determination within 30 days after presentation of the individual fee calculation study. (c) 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 179/425 (1) Upon application to the director, any person engaging in development activity requiring payment of a development impact fee may apply for and shall receive from the director a certification of the application of the development impact fee schedule to a particular development activity proposal or a certification of an individual fee determination for a particular development proposal. (2) Applications for certification shall include the following information items: a. A full and complete description of the project; b. A full and complete description of the proposed land use and the particular proposed development activity; c. A statement as to whether the applicant seeks a certification of the development impact fee schedule as applied to that particular development proposal of a certification of an individual fee determination; and d. If the applicant seeks a certification of an individual fee determination, an individual fee calculation study complying with the requirements of subsection (b) above. (3) The director shall provide an applicant with a written certification of the application of the development impact fee schedule to a particular proposed development activity within five days after the director's receipt of a completed application. The written certification of the director shall establish the development impact fee for a particular proposed development activity for a period of 180 days from the date of certification. The director shall provide the applicant with a written certification of an individual fee determination within 30 days after receipt of a completed application. The individual fee determination certified by the director shall establish the development impact fee for the 180-day period immediately following the date of such certification. Notwithstanding the issuance of any such certification, any changes in or additions to the proposed development activity different from the particular proposed development activity identified in the original application shall be subject to increased or additional development impact fees to the extent that such changes or additions require capital improvements or facilities expansions. The additional development impact fees shall be based upon the most current development impact fee schedule in effect on the date of the issuance of a building permit. (d) Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, prior to engaging in development activity generating demand and impacting city-provided services, and in addition to any other applicable requirements, the developer shall certify in writing to the director: (1) A full and complete description of the project; (2) 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 180/425 A full and complete description of the proposed land use or uses; and (3) A statement of the gross square footage applicable to each category of land use. Prior to the completion of the project, and as a condition of final inspection, the developer shall recertify in writing to the director the actual land use or uses of the project, and shall present an architect's certificate of the actual gross square footage attributable to each use. In the event that the actual use or uses and/or the actual gross square footage applicable to the actual use or uses differs from that originally certified, and in the event that the development impact fee was previously paid, the developer shall be required to pay the amount of the excess as a condition of final inspection. The amount of the excess shall be based upon the most current development impact fee schedule in effect on the date of final inspection. (Ord. of 6-19-2008, § 54-121) Sec. 54-106. - Payment of fees. (a) Any person required to pay a development impact fee pursuant to this article shall pay such fees to the director prior to the issuance of a building permit. (b) All funds collected pursuant to this article shall be identified by the development impact fee district from which it was collected and promptly transferred for deposit into the appropriate development impact fee trust fund to be held in separate accounts as provided in section 54-112. Funds shall be used solely for the purposes specified in this article. (c) In lieu of all or part of the development impact fee, the city may accept an offer to provide the items and/or services specified in subsection 54-108(2) below. Any such offer must comply with the requirements of section 54-108. The portion of the fee represented by the facility and/or infrastructure improvements shall be deemed paid when the construction is completed and accepted by the city for maintenance or when the person claiming such credit posts security for the cost of construction as provided in subsection 54-108(2)e. below. That portion of the fee represented by land dedication shall be deemed paid when the title to such land has been accepted by the city. Notwithstanding subsection (a) above, the city may issue a building permit prior to accepting title to land if the refusal to issue the permit will result in an exceptional hardship to the developer and the city is otherwise reasonably assured that title will be conveyed and accepted within a reasonable time there after. For the purposes of this subsection, an exceptional hardship shall not include a hardship solely created by the developer. (Ord. of 6-19-2008, § 54-124) Sec. 54-107. - Use of funds. (a) Funds collected as development impact fees shall be used for system improvements. No funds shall be used for periodic or routine maintenance or for any purpose not in accordance with the requirements of this article. (b) 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 181/425 Development impact fees shall be used exclusively for system improvements in the development impact fee district(s) in which the project for which the fees were paid is located. (c) Funds shall be construed as being expended in the order in which they were collected. (d) At the end of each fiscal period the director will submit to the mayor and city council an annual report describing the amount of development impact fees collected, encumbered, and expended during the preceding year by category of development impact fee districts. Monies, including any accrued interest, not encumbered in any fiscal period shall be retained in the same development impact fee trust fund(s) until the next fiscal period. (e) The city shall be entitled to retain up to three percent of all development impact fees collected as an administrative fee to offset the cost of administering this article. (f) Development impact fees may be used for the payment of principal and interest on bonds, notes or other financial obligations issued by or on behalf of the city to finance the construction or expansion facilities and/or infrastructure in accordance with this article. (Ord. of 6-19-2008, § 54-125) Sec. 54-108. - Credits. Credits against development impact fees shall be given as follows: (1) No credit shall be given for project improvements. (2) Credit shall be given for the present value of the construction of improvements or contribution or dedication of land or money by a developer subsequent to July 1, 2008, required or accepted by the city from the developer or his predecessor in title for system improvements. a. A person claiming credits shall submit to the director a project description in sufficient detail to allow the director to prepare an engineering and construction cost estimate. A person proposing credit for improvements shall present cost estimates and property appraisals prepared by qualified professionals to be used by the director in determining the amount of the credit. All construction must be carried out in accordance with applicable city or state development and design standards. A person proposing credits for land dedication shall present the director with property appraisals prepared by qualified professionals and a certified copy of the most recent assessment of the property for tax purposes to be used by the director in determining the amount of credit. However, the director retains the right to determine the amount to be credited by preparing engineering and construction cost estimates and/or property appraisals for those improvements and/or property dedications. b. 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 182/425 Credits must be claimed at the time of the application for a building permit. Any credit not so claimed shall be deemed invalid. c. In the event a developer contracts with the city to construct, fund, or contribute system improvements so that the amount of the credit created by such construction, funding, or contribution is in excess of the development impact fee which would have been otherwise due and owing, the developer shall be reimbursed for such excess construction, funding, or contribution from development impact fees paid by the development projects located in the development impact fee district which has benefitted by such improvements. d. In the event a building permit is abandoned, credit shall be given for the present value of any development impact fees for the same parcel of land paid upon issuance of such building permit. A building permit shall be deemed abandoned if no construction has commenced prior to the expiration of the building permit. e. Security in the form of a performance bond, irrevocable letter of credit, or escrow agreement shall be posted with the city, made payable to the city in the amount approved by the director equal to 110 percent of the full cost of the construction of such facility and/or infrastructure improvements. If facility and/or infrastructure improvements or construction project will not be constructed within one year of the acceptance of the offer by the city, the amount of the security shall be increased by ten percent compounded, for each year of the life of the security. The security shall be renewed and approved by the city attorney's office prior to the acceptance of the security by the city. (3) Credits are transferable from one developer to another and from one project to another provided that such credits may not be transferred to a project in a different development impact fee district. (Ord. of 6-19-2008, § 54-126) Sec. 54-109. - Exemptions. (a) The following shall be exempted from payment of development impact fees: (1) Alteration or expansion of an existing building or use of land where no additional living units are created, where the use is not changed, and whereby no additional demands for services will be created over and above those demands produced by the existing use. (2) The construction of accessory buildings or structures which will not produce additional service demands over and above those produced by the principal building or the current use of the land. (3) The replacement of a building, mobile home or structure that was in place on July 1, 2008, or the replacement of a building, mobile home or structure that was constructed subsequent thereto and for which appropriate development impact fees had been paid or otherwise provided for, with a new building, mobile home or structure 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 183/425 of the same use, provided that no additional service demands will be produced over and above those produced by the original use of the land. (b) A person claiming exemption(s) pursuant to subsections (a)(1), (2), or (3) above shall submit to the director information and documentation sufficient to permit the director to determine whether such exemption claimed is proper, and, if so, the extent of such exemption. (c) Exemptions must be applied for at the time of the application for a building permit. Any exemptions not so applied for shall be deemed waived. (Ord. of 6-19-2008, § 54-127) Sec. 54-110. - Refunds. (a) Upon application to the director by the feepayor, the city shall refund 97 percent of the development impact fee paid if service capacity is available and the building permit is rescinded or in the event development construction is otherwise denied. The city shall retain three percent of the fee paid as an administrative fee. (b) (1) Upon application to the director by the feepayor, the city shall refund 97 percent of the development impact fee paid and not expended or encumbered if the city, if after collecting the fee when service is not available, has failed to encumber the fee or commence construction within six years from the date the development impact fee was paid. The city shall retain three percent of the fee paid as an administrative fee. In determining whether development impact fees have been expended or encumbered, all fees shall be considered encumbered on a firstin, first-out (FIFO) basis. (2) When the right to a refund exists due to the city's failure to encumber development impact fees, the city shall provide written notice of entitlement of a refund to the feepayor who paid the development impact fee at the address shown on the application for development approval, or to a feepayor's successor in interest who has given the city notice of the transfer or assignment of the right or entitlement to a refund and who has provided the city with a mailing address. The city shall publish notice within 30 days after the expiration of the six-year period from the development impact fee payment date. Such published notice shall contain the heading "Notice of Entitlement to Development Impact Fee Refund." (c) A refund application shall be made to the director within one year from the date such refund becomes payable under subsections (a) and (b) above, or within one year from the date of the publication of the notice of entitlement a refund under subsection (b) above, whichever is later. Any refund not applied for within such time period shall be deemed waived. (d) A refund application shall include information and documentation sufficient to permit the director to determine whether the refund claimed is proper and, if so, the amount of such refund. A refund shall include a pro rata 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 184/425 share of interest actually earned on the unused or excess development impact fee paid. (e) All refunds shall be paid within 60 days after the director determines that such refund is due. (Ord. of 6-19-2008, § 54-128) Sec. 54-111. - Development impact fee districts established. As of July 1, 2008, there is hereby established an initial development impact fee district which shall be conterminous with the present and future incorporated limits or the service delivery area of the city. (Ord. of 6-19-2008, § 54-129) Sec. 54-112. - Development impact fee account established. (a) As of July 1, 2008, there is hereby established a development impact fee account for the initial development impact fee district established in section 54-111. Such account shall be interest-bearing. All development impact fees collected shall be deposited into this account. (b) Interest earned on funds shall be funds of the account on which it is earned and is subject to all restrictions imposed by section 54-107 (c) Funds withdrawn from these accounts must be in accordance with section 54-107 of this article. (Ord. of 6-19-2008, § 54-130) Sec. 54-113. - Review of fee schedule. The development impact fee schedule shall be reviewed by the mayor and city council at least annually; provided, however, the failure to review such fee structure shall not invalidate this article. Following such review, if changes in the fee schedule are deemed necessary, such changes may be implemented administratively, without formal amendment to this article. (Ord. of 6-19-2008, § 54-131) Sec. 54-114. - Administrative appeals. (a) Any person directly aggrieved by a decision of the director with respect to any of the following determinations shall have the right to appeal to the mayor and city council: (1) The imposition of a development impact fee; (2) The amount of a development impact fee; 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 185/425 (3) The entitlement to and/or the amount of credits to a development impact fee; (4) The entitlement to an exemption from a development impact fee; and (5) The entitlement to and/or the amount of a refund of a development impact fee. (b) Prior to any appeal to the mayor and city council, the aggrieved party shall file a written request for reconsideration with the director, who shall act upon the request within 15 days following the receipt of such request. (c) All appeals shall be taken within 15 days of the director's decision on the request for reconsideration by filing with the director a notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof. The director shall forthwith transmit to the mayor and city council all papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed is taken. The mayor and city council shall thereafter establish a reasonable date and time for a hearing on the appeal, give due notice thereof to the parties in interest, and decide the same within a reasonable period of time following the hearing. Any party taking an appeal shall have the right to appear at the hearing to present testimony and evidence and may be represented by legal council. Any person aggrieved by a decision of the mayor and city council may pursue the appeal to the Superior Court of Chatham County within 30 days after the decision of the mayor and city council is rendered. (d) A developer may pay a development impact fee under protest in order to obtain a building permit, and by making such payment shall not be prohibited from: (1) Exercising the right of appeal provided in this section; or (2) Receiving a refund of any amount deemed to have been illegally collected. (Ord. of 6-19-2008, § 54-135) Sec. 54-115. - Penalty and enforcement provisions. A violation of this article shall be a misdemeanor punishable according to the laws of the state; however, in addition to or in lieu of any criminal prosecution, the city shall have the power to sue for relief in civil court to enforce the provisions of this article. Knowingly furnishing false information to the director on any matter relating to the administration of this article shall constitute a violation thereof. (Ord. of 6-19-2008, § 54-140) Sec. 54-116. - Compliance with state law. 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 186/425 This article shall comply with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-71-1 et seq. "Entitled Development Impact Fees". The provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-71-1 et seq., are hereby adopted into this article and made part hereof. In the event portions of this article conflict with O.C.G.A. § 36-71-1 et seq., then in that event, O.C.G.A. § 36-71-1 et seq. shall control. (Ord. of 6-19-2008, § 54-145)

div.head: Chapter 58 - PUBLIC SAFETY
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building construction, ch. 14; civil emergencies, ch. 26; streets and sidewalks, ch. 66; traffic, ch. 74. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 58-1. - City fire department. The city recognizes the City of Bloomingdale Fire Department to be the exclusive fire prevention and firefighting organization in the city. All references in the fire code, except as amended, to the fire department shall be defined as the City of Bloomingdale Fire Department. (Code 1983, § 16-2; Ord. of 7-1-2008(1)) Sec. 58-2. - Monthly fees for fire protection. (a) Fees for fire protection shall be those established by resolution of the city council, and shall be published in the office of the city clerk. (b) Rates will be subject to periodic review and adjusted by city council by separate resolution as necessary to ensure adequate cost recovery for operation of the fire services provided. (Ord. of 7-1-2008(2)) Sec. 58-3. - Billing of fees for fire protection. Owners or occupants of premises receiving such service shall be billed for the fees for fire protection in the same manner and on the same monthly invoice on which water, sewer and/or garbage services are billed. The monthly invoice received shall have each charge substantiated. (Ord. of 7-1-2008(3)) Secs. 58-4—58-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY Sec. 58-31. - Created. The police department of the city is created. 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 187/425 (Code 1983, § 16-20) Sec. 58-32. - Departmental regulations. The city council is authorized to make and enforce regulations touching upon the discipline, control and government of the police department. (Code 1983, § 16-21) Sec. 58-33. - Employment of additional police officers in an emergency. Should circumstances so require, the chief of police, with the approval and consent of the mayor, or of the mayor pro tempore if the mayor is not immediately available, shall be authorized to employ for any emergency such additional police officers as to such official shall be deemed necessary; and when so employed, such additional police officers shall be subject to the same discipline as regular police officers. (Code 1983, § 16-22) Sec. 58-34. - Oath of office. All officers or persons who may be employed as special police personnel or otherwise in the police department, before entering upon the duties of the office, shall take an oath, to be administered by the mayor. (Code 1983, § 16-25) Secs. 58-35—58-60. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - CHIEF OF POLICE FOOTNOTE(S): --- (2) --- Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. Sec. 58-61. - Office created. The office of the chief of police of the city is created. (Code 1983, § 16-23) Sec. 58-62. - Appointment; term of office. The chief of police shall be appointed to that office by the city council and shall serve in that office at the pleasure of the council. (Code 1983, § 16-24) Sec. 58-63. - Oath of office. Before entering into the duties of his office, the chief of police shall take and subscribe to the following oath: I do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will truly and faithfully perform the duties of the police chief for Bloomingdale, Georgia, to the best of my ability and that I will faithfully and impartially discharge and perform all of the duties incumbent upon me as police chief according to the best of my ability and understanding, and agreeably to the laws and Constitution of the United States. I do further solemnly swear (or affirm) that I am not 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 188/425 the holder of any unaccounted for public money due this state or any political subdivision or authority thereof; that I am not the holder of any office of trust under the Government of the United States, any other state, or any foreign state which I am, by the laws of the State of Georgia, prohibited from holding; and that I will support the Constitution of the United States and of this state. So help me God. (Code 1983, § 16-25) Sec. 58-64. - Salary. The chief of police shall receive such salary as may be fixed by the city council. The salary of this officer shall be paid in the manner that shall be specified by the council. (Code 1983, § 16-26) Sec. 58-65. - In charge of department. The chief of police shall have charge and control of the police department, under the supervision and direction of the mayor and the city council. (Code 1983, § 16-27) Sec. 58-66. - Duties. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to: (1) Preserve all of the property of the city pertaining to the police department. (2) Place upon an information docket the names of all of the following persons when gaining knowledge thereof: All persons violating any of the ordinances of the city, all felons and rioters, all disorderly or suspected persons who may be found misbehaving themselves, all persons who may be in any manner disturbing the public peace, all persons who may, in any way, assault, oppose or resist a police officer when engaged in the discharge of official duties, and all persons who violate any of the laws of the state or of the United States within the corporate limits of the city. The chief of police shall arrest and take into custody all such persons, or cause the same to be done. (3) Attend all sessions of the municipal court; and to sign and execute all summonses, subpoenas and other processes from the municipal court. (4) Pass upon the sufficiency of bonds, for criminal offenses, and to take and accept bonds for criminal offenses secured by either corporate surety, cash deposits or real estate as the exigency of the criminal charge may require, in bondable cases for violations of ordinances of the city or for violations of laws of the state or of the United States, and in lieu of such bond, to commit the offender to jail, until such time as the alleged violation can be heard and determined in the municipal court, or the defendant is transferred to another jurisdiction. (5) Carry out and execute and enforce all judgments that shall be rendered in the municipal court. (6) 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 189/425 Do and perform all acts, things and services of the office of city marshal, as such are prescribed by the general state law. (Code 1983, § 16-28)

div.head: Chapter 62 - SOLID WASTE
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- Cross reference— Buildings and building construction, ch. 14; environment, ch. 34; manufactured homes, ch. 42; utilities, ch. 78. State Law reference— Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; local, multijurisdictional and regional solid waste plans, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-31.1; Georgia Hazardous Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-60 et seq.; unlawful placement of signs within right-of-way of public road, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-51; authorization to provide garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(2). ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 62-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Apartments, roominghouses, hotels, tourist courts, motels means and includes those facilities licensed as such by the city in which two or more units are rented or offered to the public for rental. Ashes means the residue resulting from the burning of wood, coal, coke or other combustible material. Disposal means and includes the storage, collection, disposal or handling of refuse. Family dwelling unit means a structure providing housing for a collective body of persons forming one household under a common head. Garbage means all animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking or consumption of foods. Refuse means all solid wastes, except body wastes, and shall include garbage, ashes and rubbish. Rubbish means and includes glass, metal, and nonputrescible solid wastes. (Code 1983, § 9-1) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 62-2. - Refuse containers. (a) Refuse containers shall be made of durable watertight, rust-resistant materials having a closefitting lid and handles to facilitate collection. (b) 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 190/425 Refuse containers for residences shall be of not less than ten gallons nor more than 32 gallons in capacity. Containers for commercial establishments shall not exceed 30 gallons in capacity. (c) It shall be unlawful to permit the accumulation of residue of liquids, solids, or a combination of such material on the bottom or sides of containers, it being the intention of this provision that the interior of containers shall be kept clean by thorough rinsing and draining as often as necessary. (Code 1983, § 9-2) Sec. 62-3. - Storage of refuse. (a) Each household, commercial establishment or person having refuse shall provide approved refuse containers and shall place and keep all refuse therein as provided in this chapter. (b) It shall be unlawful to place refuse in any street, alley or any other public place, or upon private property, whether or not owned by such person, unless such refuse is placed in an approved container, as provided in this chapter. (c) It shall be unlawful to place refuse in any stream or body of water, or in any place inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter. (Code 1983, § 9-3) Sec. 62-4. - Preparation, storage, and collection of residential rubbish. (a) Except for those items defined below in subsection (d) of this section, residential rubbish shall be containerized as specified in section 62-2 to receive regular collection service. (b) To qualify for regular rubbish collection service, items of rubbish shall also include small tree branches, brush or other small items not regularly containerized, if they meet the following criteria: (1) Cut and baled, tied, bundled, stacked, packaged, or bagged a neat and orderly manner at the location for the placement of rubbish and refuse containers; (2) Loadable in the city's limb grinder or the hopper of a rear-loading refuse packer truck (i.e., lengths no greater than three feet and weights no greater than 50 pounds); and (3) Loadable in five minutes or less. 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 191/425 (c) Large tree branches, heavy brush, furniture, appliances and other large objects of excess house rubbish which cannot be containerized shall not be placed on the side streets for collection unless special arrangements for collection have been made. The city shall collect such items only by special arrangement. Arrangements for such collections shall be made through the city clerk's office. Special fees shall be paid for special collection services computed on the basis of crew hours required to make the collection. There shall be a minimum fee charge. In lieu of such special arrangements with the city, property owners or occupants may arrange for other suitable and prompt collection and disposal of such rubbish. Until collected, such rubbish shall be stored or stacked in a neat and orderly manner. Fees due for special collection service may be billed along with the fee for water service, and shall be due and payable at the same time and under the same conditions as fees for water service. (d) Collection service shall not be provided for the following items: (1) Materials used in the construction or remodeling of buildings or resulting from the demolition of buildings. (2) Logs, stumps or limbs resulting from commercial or major tree trimming operations. (3) Explosive or flammable liquids and materials or other hazardous waste. (4) Materials which the city sanitation director reasonably deems too dangerous for city employees to handle. (Code 1983, § 9-4; Ord. of 8-19-1999(1)) Sec. 62-5. - Sanitary hazards. It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of a residence or commercial establishment to allow an accumulation of garbage, refuse or rubbish which poses a health, safety or welfare hazard to the citizenry of the city. (Code 1983, § 9-5) Sec. 62-6. - Placement of containers for collection. Refuse containers shall, for the purposes of collection, be placed at ground level and be made readily accessible to the collector. They shall be placed on the side of the street from which collection is to be made. (Code 1983, § 9-6) Sec. 62-7. - Fees. Fees to be charged under the provisions of this chapter shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. (Ord. of 6-15-1989, § 9-14; Ord. of 12-5-1996(1), § 9-14; Ord. of 8-12-2000) 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 192/425 Sec. 62-8. - Billing, due date, penalties, etc. (a) Bills for this charge shall be rendered monthly to the property owner, tenant, or occupant depending on the particular situation or agreement. Charges for services rendered shall be due and payable on the first of the following month. After the fifteenth day of the month billed, charges shall become delinquent and subject to a ten percent late charge. (b) In the case where a bill is being rendered to a tenant or occupant, and if such tenant or occupant should not pay his or her fee for this service within 45 days from due date, the responsibility for paying such fee falls to the property owner upon whose property the tenant or occupant is living. At the end of the above mentioned 45 days, the clerk's office shall within a reasonable time notify the property owner by certified mail of the delinquent fee and the said property owner is responsible for such delinquent fee and shall pay such within 15 days from the time of receiving notice. If such property owner has not paid delinquent fee within the above mentioned 15 days, the city may move against the property owner for collection using the appropriate legal remedy. (Code 1983, § 9-7; Ord. of 4-3-1986; Ord. of 6-15-1989, § 9-7) Sec. 62-9. - Foreclosing lien. (a) The owner of the premises and the real property shall be liable for all charges incurred by the city for the clearing of the weeds, brush, trash, etc. When charges are due and remain unpaid for a period of 60 days, the city may cause an execution to be issued by the city clerk against the owner of the premises for which the weeds, brush, trash, services are furnished, and any other persons as may be liable therefore. The execution shall be a lien upon said premises, and when recorded in the general execution docket of the county shall be a lien upon all the property of the defendant in execution from the date of such record. The execution may be levied by the marshal of the city, and after advertisement and other proceedings as in the case of sale for the nonpayment of taxes, the property levied upon shall be sold at public outcry to the highest bidder. Such sale shall vest an absolute title in the purchaser; provided that the defendant shall have the right to file an affidavit denying that the whole or any part of the amount for which the execution issued is due, and stating what amount such defendant admits to be due, which amounts so admitted to be due shall be paid or collected before the affidavit is received, and the affidavit received for the balance. All affidavits shall set out in detail the reasons the affiant claims the amount is not due, and when received by the city marshal shall be returned to a court of competent jurisdiction, to the superior court of the county, and there tried and the issue determined. (b) Or, the city may elect to treat the delinquent payment as a debt and may sue to collect such debt. In the case of a water and/or sewer user who is delinquent in the payment of his garbage bill, the city may elect to terminate his water supply. (Code 1983, § 9-8; Ord. of 6-15-1989, § 9-8; Ord. of 2-17-2005(2)) Sec. 62-10. - Garbage deposit. Effective July 1, 1986, a garbage deposit is hereby required. Any new garbage customer after this date shall pay a cash security deposit as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. Deposits shall be refunded after two years on June 30th of the second calendar year beginning June 30, 1988, if service is not terminated prior to that date. (Ord. of 4-3-1986, § 9-12) 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 193/425 Sec. 62-11. - Waste resulting from construction or demolition. All construction and demolition contractors or other responsible persons shall provide on-site refuse receptacles, bulk containers or detachable containers for loose debris, paper, building material wastes, scrap building materials, and other trash produced by those working on the site. In the case of construction activities, such containers may be provided at the commencement of any framing. All of the above-mentioned materials shall be containerized by the end of each day, and the site shall be kept in a reasonably clean and litter free condition. The number of refuse receptacles, bulk containers, or detachable containers shall be determined by the size of the job. Prior to the commencement of any work, the contractor shall also provide on-site portable toilets for use by their employees and/or agents. Dirt, mud, construction materials, or other debris deposited upon any public or private property as a result of construction or demolition shall be immediately removed by the contractor. Construction sites shall be kept clean and orderly at all times. (Ord. of 1-21-1999) Cross reference— Buildings and building construction, ch. 18. Sec. 62-12. - Municipal jurisdiction. (a) It shall be mandatory that all owners, occupants, tenants and lessors of residential buildings, offices or businesses and commercial buildings and premises, and the same shall be required to accept such collection and removal services as it relates to the disposal of garbage, trash, rubbish and other debris with the municipal jurisdiction or the city. Occupants shall be defined as someone who is living in or occupying some other persons property whether or not they are paying rent. A property owner shall be given a reasonable time, at least 60 days, to remove a squatter before being responsible for his garbage payment. (b) Any person, homeowner, or business may elect to have additional collection, removal and disposal of garbage, trash, rubbish, and other debris provided they have paid the city their proper fee and the supplier of the above mentioned services has complied with all the city regulations, permits and license requirements. (Ord. of 6-15-1989, § 9-13) Sec. 62-13. - Responsibility of owners of multi-unit complex to collect fees. (a) Trailer park owners and operators and the owner or manager of apartment projects shall be required to collect and to remit to the city clerk the required sanitation fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk from each mobile home or apartment resident whose mobile home or apartment is situated within said trailer park or apartment project by the tenth day of each month. (b) The city is at liberty to make special agreement with the above mentioned owners or managers if it is advantageous to the city. Special agreements may include fee schedules and garbage pickups. (Ord. of 6-15-1989, § 9-15) Sec. 62-14. - Garbage picking prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to ransack, rummage or plunder any trash can or other receptacle where trash or other garbage is kept with the city. 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 194/425 (Ord. of 6-15-1989, § 9-16) Secs. 62-15—62-40. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - YARD TRIMMINGS DISPOSAL REGULATIONS Sec. 62-41. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Commercial solid waste means all types of solid waste generated by stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses, and other nonmanufacturing activities, excluding residential and industrial waste. Composting means the controlled biological decomposition of organic matter into stable, odor-free humus. Leachate collection system means a system at a landfill for collection of the leachate which may percolate through the waste and into the soils surrounding the landfill. Municipal solid waste means any solid waste derived from households, including garbage, trash and sanitary waste in septic tanks and includes solid waste from single-family and multifamily residences, hotels, and motels, bunkhouses, campgrounds, picnic grounds, and day use recreation areas. The term includes yard trimmings and commercial solid waste but does not include solid waste from mining, agricultural, or silvicultural operations or industrial processes or operations. Municipal solid waste disposal facility means any facility or location where the final deposition of any amount of municipal solid waste occurs, whether or not mixed with or including commercial or industrial solid waste, including, but not limited to, municipal solid waste landfills. Municipal solid waste landfill means a disposal facility where any amount of the municipal solid waste, whether or not mixed with or including commercial waste, industrial waste, nonhazardous sludges or small quantity generator hazardous waste, is disposed of by means of placing an approved cover thereon. Yard trimmings means leaves, brush, grass clippings, shrub and tree prunings, discarded Christmas trees, nursery and greenhouse vegetative residuals, and vegetative matter resulting from landscaping, development and maintenance, other than mining, agricultural and silvicultural operations. (Ord. of 10-3-1996(3), § 9-50) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 62-42. - Penalties. Any person violating any section of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-11 of this Code. (Ord. of 10-3-1996(3), § 9-53) Sec. 62-43. - Placement and disposal of yard trimmings, prohibitions. (a) It shall be unlawful to place or mix yard trimmings with municipal solid waste within the city. If yard trimmings are bagged, they shall be placed in paper bags only. (b) 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 195/425 Yard trimmings shall not be disposed of at any municipal solid waste disposal facility having a liner and leachate collection system or requiring vertical expansion located within the city. (Ord. of 10-3-1996(3), § 9-51) Sec. 62-44. - Sorting, storing, composting, and collecting yard trimmings. Yard trimmings shall be handled in the following hierarchy: (1) Naturalized, low maintenance landscaping requiring little or no cutting; (2) Grass cycling by mowing it high and letting it lie; (3) Stacking branches into brush piles for use as wildlife habitats and for gradual decomposition into the soil; (4) Composting on the site where the material was grown, followed by incorporation of the finished compost into the soil at that site; (5) Chipping woody material on the site where such material was generated; (6) Collecting yard trimmings and transporting them to another site to be chipped or composted for later use; (7) Chipping woody material for later use as fiber fuel; and (8) Collecting yard trimmings and transporting them to solid waste facilities other than municipal solid waste disposal facilities which have a liner and leachate collection system or which continue to operate only because they have been approved for vertical expansion. (Ord. of 10-3-1996(3), § 9-52)

div.head: Chapter 66 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- Cross reference— Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, widening, paving, etc., any street or public way in the city saved from repeal, § 1-6(6); any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes for such improvements saved from repeal, § 1-6(9); any ordinance establishing or prescribing street grades in the city saved from repeal, § 1-6(15); drinking, possessing alcoholic beverages in public, § 6-4; buildings and building construction, ch. 14; solicitors, peddlers, canvassers, § 18-161 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 196/425 et seq.; cable communications, ch. 22; flood control, ch. 38; manufactured homes, ch. 42; street system, parking in manufactured home parks, § 42-121 et seq.; parks and recreation, ch. 50; planning and development, ch. 54; public safety, ch. 58; traffic, ch. 74; utilities, ch. 78; zoning, app. A; subdivisions, app. B; design standards for streets in subdivisions, app. B, § 501. State Law reference— State, county and municipal road systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-1 et seq.; municipal street systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-90 et seq.; powers with respect to municipal street system, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-92; regulation of maintenance and use of public roads generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1 et seq.; power to construct and maintain roads, including curbs, sidewalks, streetlights and devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4). ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Secs. 66-1—66-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS Sec. 66-31. - Permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person, under any pretext whatsoever, to make or place an excavation, embankment or obstruction in any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public way in the city until written application has been made for a permit from the city clerk authorizing the same. (Code 1983, § 17-1) Sec. 66-32. - Emergency procedure. If an emergency exists where the health and safety of the citizens of the city are in danger, or for the immediate preservation of property, an excavation, embankment or obstruction may be made to the extent of abating the dangerous condition or situation without first obtaining the permit required by this article; provided, upon relieving the existing emergency, the person making the excavation shall notify the city clerk and otherwise comply with the requirements of this article regulating same. (Code 1983, § 17-1) Sec. 66-33. - Application for permit; issuance. Each application for a permit under this article shall describe the character of the work to be done, a full description of the premises where such work is to be done and shall be signed by the person applying for the permit. (Code 1983, § 17-2) Sec. 66-34. - Issuance of permit. A permit required by this article shall be issued in duplicate, the original to be delivered to the party applying therefor, and one copy to be filed in the office of the city clerk, together with the application. (Code 1983, § 17-2) Sec. 66-35. - Surety bond. No permit required by this article shall be issued to any person in the city until such person shall have filed with the city a bond in the sum of $1,000.00, with good and sufficient sureties, to be approved by the city clerk. If a bonded franchise company does the work, it shall be required to file only one bond. The conditions of the bond required in this section are as follows: 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 197/425 (1) The permittee will perform all work in a good and workmanlike manner in strict accordance with the provisions of this article. (2) At the permittee's own expense, the permittee will backfill any excavations in any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public way in the city, so as to return the same to the original or better condition. (3) The permittee will place and maintain lights and guardrails around all excavations, materials or equipment left in any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public place of the city. (4) The permittee will hold the city harmless from all damages, real or asserted, that may occur by reason of the operation. (Code 1983, § 17-3) Sec. 66-36. - Restoration of surface. When any part of any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public way in the city shall be excavated, torn, dug or taken up for any purpose or when an embankment or obstruction is placed thereon, the person doing the same shall, immediately upon the completion of such work, and within at least ten days after the completion of such work, return the earth and ram and puddle the same to a firm and solid bearing and in such manner as will entirely prevent the settling of such earth, and shall also relay the paving, macadamizing or gravel, as the case may be, in a skillful and permanent manner, and in every case, to the satisfaction of the city clerk. Failure to comply with the requirements of this section shall constitute an offense, and each day such failure continues shall constitute a separate offense. (Code 1983, § 17-4) Sec. 66-37. - Lights and barricades. It shall be unlawful for any person to make any excavation, embankment or obstruction of whatsoever kind in the city, whether the same be in, along or near any street or sidewalk, alley or other public way, of any kind without placing proper guardrails and signal lights or other warnings, at, in or around the same, sufficient to warn the public of such excavation, embankment or obstruction, and to protect all persons using reasonable care from accident on account of the same. (Code 1983, § 17-5) Sec. 66-38. - Special street cleaning or repair. (a) The term "special cleaning or repair", as used in this section and sections 66-39 and 66-40, shall include cleaning, resurfacing, restoration of gravel and similar repairs made necessary by prohibited acts, neglect, or conditions. (b) 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 198/425 Any act, neglect, or omission or any condition caused or allowed to continue which creates, results in, or causes a condition in or upon any public street, sidewalk, or storm drain which requires special cleaning or repair of such street, sidewalk or storm drain is hereby prohibited. (c) Prohibited acts, neglect, omissions, and conditions which result in requiring special cleaning or repair of such street shall include, but not be limited to: (1) The hauling of dirt, debris, and materials removed from the sites of construction or reconstruction of buildings or structures, or waste materials of any kind, in such manner that any portion of such dirt, debris, or materials is spilled, lost, dropped or left upon the streets or sidewalks. (2) Depositing or leaving upon the streets or sidewalks or other ways of mud, dirt, or other material as the result of the use of trucks, construction equipment or machinery, regardless of whether such materials are spilled, lost, or dropped in transit, or are deposited upon the surface of the street or public property by the tires and wheels of such trucks, construction equipment or machinery. (3) The grading of lots, or other land at elevations higher than the street, sidewalk, or other way, or any other acts, neglect, or conditions created or allowed to exist upon such property which result in mud, dirt, soil, gravel, debris or other materials being washed onto streets or sidewalks or into the storm drainage system. (4) The tearing up of streets or sidewalks or other ways as a result of the use of trucks, construction equipment, or machinery coming to and from construction sites. (d) Special cleaning or repairing of streets, sidewalks, and the storm drainage system shall be deemed to be required when their condition is such that the public health, safety, welfare, or public use of the same is threatened, limited, or impaired; the use and enjoyment of property abutting such streets or sidewalks is diminished or limited; or substantial damage is caused to the streets, sidewalks, or drainage facilities or to such abutting property. (Ord. of 10-4-2001, § 1(17-6)) Sec. 66-39. - Performance of work; failure to complete; stop work order. (a) Any person whose act, neglect, or omission causes or permits a condition to exist or continue upon any street, sidewalk, or other way, or in any storm drain, which condition requires special cleaning or repair shall, upon receipt of written notice from the city, perform such special cleaning and repair upon and to such street, sidewalk, or storm drain. (b) Upon failure of the person responsible to perform special cleaning and repair after notice, the director of public works may cause the same to be performed by his department, and in such event shall keep records of the costs 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 199/425 of such work, which may be computed on the basis of reasonably established per-mile, or per-hour, or both costs of the use of equipment, plus labor and materials, including water, likewise computed at the cost to the city. (c) Whenever any construction work is being performed in a manner as to violate subsection (a) of this section and to create a hazardous condition, the mayor may order the specific part of such work which is creating the violation to be immediately stopped. The order to stop shall be in writing to the person whose act, neglect, or omission causes or permits a condition to exist or continue, and should state the specific work to be stopped, the specific reasons therefor, and the conditions under which the work may be resumed. Violation of a stop order shall constitute an offense under this Code and shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. For any offense continued from day to day, each day's continuance thereof shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. of 10-4-2001, § 1(17-7)) Sec. 66-40. - Reimbursement of city, civil penalty; payment of. (a) Any person whose act, neglect, or omission or who, by permitting a condition to continue (whether done or neglected directly or through an agent, servant or employee), causes additional expense to the city for necessary special cleaning or repairs shall reimburse the city for its expenses upon receipt of an itemized statement of expenses submitted by the city, and upon failure to reimburse the city shall incur and be liable to the city for a civil penalty of $1,000.00, in addition to such expenses. (b) The department of public works shall send to any person responsible for additional expense to the city an itemized statement of the expense incurred and request for reimbursement. The city attorney is authorized to bring suit in the name of the city to recover any such unpaid expenses and civil penalties. (Ord. of 10-4-2001, § 1(17-8)) Secs. 66-41—66-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - STREET NUMBERING Sec. 66-71. - Penalties. If the owner or occupant or person in charge of any house or building refuses to comply with the terms of this article by failing to affix the number assigned by the city planning commission pursuant to section 66-72 within 60 days after notification, or by failing within such 60-day period to remove any old house numbers affixed to such house, or house entrance, or elsewhere, which may be confused with the number assigned thereto, he may be charged with a misdemeanor and punished within the discretion of the municipal judge. (Ord. of 3-4-1988, § 19-4) Sec. 66-72. - Designation of street numbers. (a) Street numbers for dwelling units and places of business on all public and private streets shall be assigned by the city planning commission in accordance with its administrative procedures. (b) The city planning commission shall keep a record of all numbers assigned under this article. 4/30/2019 Bloomingdale, GA Code of Ordinances 200/425 (Ord. of 3-4-1988, § 19-1) Sec. 66-73. - Posting of designated street address. (a) The owner or occupant or person in charge of any house or building to which a number has been assigned will be notified in writing by the city clerk or representative thereof of the number assigned to the house or building at any time after March 4, 1988.
